statements.name: PROC EXPORT
statements.description: The EXPORT procedure reads a SAS data set (or CAS table if you have a connection to CAS) and writes the data to an external data file.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: libref.SAS data set specifies the input SAS data set with either a one- or two-level SAS name (library and member name). If you specify a one-level name, by default, the EXPORT procedure uses either the SASUSER library (if assigned) or the WORK library (if SAS system option USER is not assigned).

arguments.name: OUTFILE=
arguments.description: specifies the complete path and file name or a fileref for the output PC file or delimited external file. If the name does not include special characters (such as question marks), lowercase characters, or spaces, omit the quotation marks.

arguments.name: OUTTABLE=
arguments.description: specifies the DBMS output table. If the name does not include special characters (such as question marks), lowercase characters, or spaces, omit the quotation marks. The DBMS table name might be case sensitive.

arguments.name: SAS
arguments.description: specify SAS data set options. For example, if the data set that you are exporting has an assigned password, you can use these options: ALTER=, PW=, READ=, or WRITE=. To export only data that meets a specified condition, you can use the WHERE= data set option.

arguments.name: DBMS=
arguments.description: DBMS= specifies the type of external data source the EXPORT procedure creates. To export to a DBMS table, specify DBMS= using a supported database identifier. For example, DBMS=CSV specifies to import a delimited file with comma-separated values.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: writes SAS label names as column names to the exported table. If SAS label names do not exist, then the variable names are used as column names in the exported table.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: overwrites an existing file. For a Microsoft Access database or an Excel workbook, REPLACE overwrites the target table or spreadsheet. If you do not specify REPLACE, the EXPORT procedure does not overwrite an existing file.

arguments.name: file-format-specific-statements
arguments.description: See for the supported syntax for your DBMS.
